ai-an10:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:1.1.3_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an10:1.1.3_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-an10:1.2.1_0: “Sir, what is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics?”
ai-an10:1.2.2_0: “Ānanda, the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics is having no regrets.”
ai-an10:1.3.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of having no regrets?”
ai-an10:1.3.2_0: “Joy is the purpose and benefit of having no regrets.”
ai-an10:1.4.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of joy?”
ai-an10:1.5.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of rapture?”
ai-an10:1.6.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of tranquility?”
ai-an10:1.7.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of bliss?”
ai-an10:1.8.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of immersion?”
ai-an10:1.9.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing?”
ai-an10:1.10.1_0: “But what’s the purpose and benefit of disillusionment?”
ai-an10:1.10.2_0: “Knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an10:1.11.1_0: So, Ānanda, the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics is not having regrets.
ai-an10:1.11.2_0: Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets.
ai-an10:1.11.3_0: Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy.
ai-an10:1.11.4_0: Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture.
ai-an10:1.11.5_0: Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility.
ai-an10:1.11.6_0: Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss.
ai-an10:1.11.7_0: Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion.
ai-an10:1.11.8_0: Disillusionment and dispassion is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing.
ai-an10:1.11.9_0: Disillusionment is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an10:1.11.10_0: So, Ānanda, skillful ethics progressively lead up to the highest.”
ai-an10:2.1.1_0: “Mendicants, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethical conduct, need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.3_0: It’s only natural that an ethical person has no regrets.
ai-an10:2.1.4_0: When you have no regrets you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.6_0: It’s only natural that joy springs up when you have no regrets.
ai-an10:2.1.7_0: When you feel joy you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.9_0: It’s only natural that joy arises, when you’re joyful.
ai-an10:2.1.10_0: When your mind is full of rapture you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.12_0: It’s only natural that your body becomes tranquil when your mind is full of rapture.
ai-an10:2.1.13_0: When your body is tranquil you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.15_0: It’s only natural to feel bliss when your body is tranquil.
ai-an10:2.1.16_0: When you feel bliss you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.17_0: ‘May my mind be immersed in samādhi!’
ai-an10:2.1.18_0: It’s only natural for the mind to be immersed in samādhi when you feel bliss.
ai-an10:2.1.19_0: When your mind is immersed in samādhi you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.21_0: It’s only natural to truly know and see when your mind is immersed in samādhi.
ai-an10:2.1.22_0: When you truly know and see you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.24_0: It’s only natural to grow disillusioned when you truly know and see.
ai-an10:2.1.25_0: When you’re disillusioned and dispassionate you need not make a wish:
ai-an10:2.1.26_0: ‘May I realize the knowledge and vision of freedom!’
ai-an10:2.1.27_0: It’s only natural to realize the knowledge and vision of freedom when you’re dispassionate.
ai-an10:2.2.1_0: And so, mendicants, the knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an10:2.2.2_0: Disillusionment and dispassion is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing.
ai-an10:2.2.3_0: Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion.
ai-an10:2.2.4_0: Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss.
ai-an10:2.2.5_0: Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility.
ai-an10:2.2.6_0: Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture.
ai-an10:2.2.7_0: Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy.
ai-an10:2.2.8_0: Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets.
ai-an10:2.2.9_0: Not having regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.
ai-an10:2.2.10_0: And so, mendicants, good qualities flow on and fill up from one to the other, for going from the near shore to the far shore.”

ai-an10:7.1.1_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-an10:7.1.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-an10:7.1.2_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
ai-an10:7.2.1_0: “Could it be, reverend Sāriputta, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world.
ai-an10:7.2.1_1: but I perceive it as non-percipient.”
ai-an10:7.3.1_1: Not perceiving the next world in another world,
ai-an10:7.3.1_2: but I perceive it as non-percipient.”
ai-an10:7.4.1_1: but I perceive it as non-percipient.”
ai-an10:7.4.2_0: “Reverend Ānanda, one time I was staying right here at Sāvatthī in the Dark Forest.
ai-an10:7.4.3_0: There I gained a state of immersion like this. I didn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And I didn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an10:7.5.1_0: “But at that time what did Reverend Sāriputta perceive?”
ai-an10:7.5.2_0: “One perception arose in me and another perception ceased: ‘The cessation of continued existence is extinguishment. The cessation of continued existence is extinguishment.’
ai-an10:7.5.3_0: Suppose there was a burning pile of twigs. One flame would arise and another would cease.
ai-an10:7.5.4_0: In the same way, one perception arose in me and another perception ceased: ‘The cessation of continued existence is extinguishment. The cessation of continued existence is extinguishment.’
ai-an10:7.5.5_0: At that time I perceived that the cessation of continued existence is extinguishment.”

ai-an10:8.2.5_0: they’re not an expert in the training ...
ai-an10:8.2.6_0: they don’t stay in the wilderness, in remote lodgings ...
ai-an10:8.2.7_0: they don’t get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty ...
ai-an10:8.2.8_0: they don’t realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-an10:8.2.9_0: So they’re incomplete in that respect.

ai-an10:11.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five factors, using and frequenting lodgings with five factors, will soon realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-an10:11.2.1_0: And how does a mendicant have five factors?
ai-an10:11.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
ai-an10:11.2.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha ...’
ai-an10:11.2.4_0: He is rarely ill or unwell. His stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.
ai-an10:11.2.5_0: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

ai-an10:11.3.2_0: It’s when a lodging is not too far, not too near, and suitable for going to walk.
ai-an10:11.3.3_0: It’s not bothered by people by day, and at night it’s quiet and still.
ai-an10:11.3.4_0: There’s little disturbance from flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles.
ai-an10:11.3.5_0: While staying in that lodging the necessities of life—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.
ai-an10:11.3.6_0: And in that lodging there are several senior mendicants who are very learned, knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the texts on monastic training, and the outlines.

ai-an10:11.3.8_0: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’

ai-an10:11.3.10_0: That’s how a lodging has five factors.

ai-an10:12.1.1_0: “Mendicants, in this teaching and training a mendicant who has given up five factors and possesses five factors is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.
ai-an10:12.1.2_0: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?
ai-an10:12.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
ai-an10:12.1.4_0: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.
ai-an10:12.2.1_0: And how does a mendicant have five factors?
ai-an10:12.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has the entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an10:12.2.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has five factors.

ai-an10:13.1.3_0: The five lower fetters and the five higher fetters.
ai-an10:13.1.4_0: What are the five lower fetters?
ai-an10:13.1.5_0: Identity view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, sensual desire, and ill will.
ai-an10:13.1.6_0: These are the five lower fetters.
ai-an10:13.2.1_0: What are the five higher fetters?
ai-an10:13.2.2_0: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.
ai-an10:13.2.3_0: These are the five higher fetters.
ai-an10:14.1.1_0: “Mendicants, monk or nun who has not given up five kinds of emotional barrenness and has not cut off five emotional shackles can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

ai-an10:15.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an10:15.1.2_0: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence,
ai-an10:15.1.2_1: and diligence is said to be the best of them.
ai-an10:15.2.1_0: The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.
ai-an10:15.2.2_0: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence,
ai-an10:15.2.2_1: and diligence is said to be the best of them.
ai-an10:15.3.1_0: The rafters of a bungalow all lean to the peak, slope to the peak, and meet at the peak, so the peak is said to be the topmost of them all.
ai-an10:15.3.2_0: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence,
ai-an10:15.3.2_1: and diligence is said to be the best of them.
ai-an10:15.4.1_0: Of all kinds of fragrant root, spikenard is said to be the best.
ai-an10:15.5.1_0: Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.
ai-an10:15.6.1_0: Of all kinds of fragrant flower, jasmine is said to be the best.
ai-an10:15.7.1_0: All lesser kings are vassals of a wheel-turning monarch, so the wheel-turning monarch is said to be the foremost of them all.
ai-an10:15.8.1_0: The radiance of all the stars is not worth a sixteenth part of the moon’s radiance, so the moon’s radiance is said to be the best of them all.
ai-an10:15.9.1_0: After the rainy season the sky is clear and cloudless. And when the sun rises, it dispels all the darkness from the sky as it shines and glows and radiates.
ai-an10:15.10.2_0: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence,
ai-an10:15.10.2_1: and diligence is said to be the best of them.”
ai-an10:16.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these ten people are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.
ai-an10:16.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:16.1.3_0: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha; a Buddha awakened for themselves; one freed both ways; one freed by wisdom; one attained to view; one freed by faith; a follower by faith; a follower by faith; a follower of the teachings; a member of the spiritual family.
ai-an10:16.1.4_0: These are the ten people who are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.”
ai-an10:16.1.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an10:17.1.1_0: “Mendicants, you should live with a protector, not without one.
ai-an10:17.1.2_0: Living without a protector is suffering.

ai-an10:17.1.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:17.1.5_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:17.1.7_0: This is a quality that serves as protector.

ai-an10:17.2.3_0: This is a quality that serves as protector.

ai-an10:17.4.3_0: This is a quality that serves as protector.

ai-an10:17.5.3_0: This is a quality that serves as protector.

ai-an10:19.1.1_0: “There are these ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.
ai-an10:19.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:19.1.3_0: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.
ai-an10:19.1.4_0: These are the ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.”
ai-an10:20.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
ai-an10:20.1.2_0: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-an10:20.2.1_0: “There are these ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.
ai-an10:20.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:20.2.3_0: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.
ai-an10:20.3.1_0: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?
ai-an10:20.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
ai-an10:20.3.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.
ai-an10:20.4.1_0: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?
ai-an10:20.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
ai-an10:20.4.3_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-an10:20.4.4_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-an10:20.4.5_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-an10:20.4.6_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-an10:20.4.7_0: Knowing a thought with the mind, they’re neither happy nor sad, but remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
ai-an10:20.4.8_0: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.
ai-an10:20.5.1_0: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?
ai-an10:20.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.
ai-an10:20.5.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.
ai-an10:20.6.1_0: And how does a mendicant have four supports?
ai-an10:20.6.2_0: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.
ai-an10:20.6.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.
ai-an10:20.7.1_0: And how has a mendicant eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?
ai-an10:20.7.2_0: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. For example:
ai-an10:20.7.3_0: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-an10:20.7.4_0: All have given up, given up, let go of, given up, relinquished, and relinquished,
ai-an10:20.7.5_0: That’s how a mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.
ai-an10:20.8.1_0: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?
ai-an10:20.8.2_0: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual life.
ai-an10:20.8.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.
ai-an10:20.9.1_0: And how has a mendicant unsullied intentions?
ai-an10:20.9.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up intentions of sensuality, malice, and cruelty.
ai-an10:20.9.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.
ai-an10:20.10.1_0: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?
ai-an10:20.10.2_0: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-an10:20.10.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.
ai-an10:20.11.1_0: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?
ai-an10:20.11.2_0: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-an10:20.11.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.
ai-an10:20.12.1_0: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?
ai-an10:20.12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
ai-an10:20.12.3_0: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.
ai-an10:20.13.1_0: Whether in the past, future, or present, all those noble ones of the past, all of them are the ten noble ones.
ai-an10:20.13.2_0: Whatever noble ones in the future will in the future, all of them will and all of them a noble disciple.
ai-an10:20.13.3_0: or present who are noble, all of them have the ten rains residences.
ai-an10:20.13.4_0: These are the ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.”
ai-an10:20.13.6_0: The second sub-chapter on monasteries is finished.
ai-an10:21.1.1_0: “Mendicants, towards the lion, king of beasts, came out in the evening time.
ai-an10:21.1.2_0: he leaves the mango tree transfer.
ai-an10:21.1.3_0: looks all around the four directions,
ai-an10:21.1.4_0: and roars his lion’s roar three times.
ai-an10:21.1.5_0: if she roars her lion’s roar three times, and then departs;
ai-an10:21.1.7_0: Thinking: ‘May I not accidentally injure any little creatures that happen to be in the wrong place.’
ai-an10:21.2.1_0: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-an10:21.2.2_0: When the Realized One teaches Dhamma to an assembly, this is his lion’s roar.
ai-an10:21.3.1_0: The Realized One possesses ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
ai-an10:21.3.3_0: Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible.
ai-an10:21.3.4_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
ai-an10:21.4.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of causes and reasons.
ai-an10:21.4.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.5.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands where all paths of practice lead.
ai-an10:21.5.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.6.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the world with its many and diverse elements.
ai-an10:21.6.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.7.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the diverse attitudes of sentient beings.
ai-an10:21.7.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.8.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after comprehending them with his mind.
ai-an10:21.8.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.9.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.
ai-an10:21.9.2_1: This is their power of a Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.10.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives.
ai-an10:21.10.1_1: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-an10:21.10.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One.
ai-an10:21.11.1_0: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an10:21.11.1_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-an10:21.11.1_2: They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an10:21.11.1_3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an10:21.11.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One.
ai-an10:21.11.2_1: They understand how this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.12.1_0: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-an10:21.12.2_0: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. ...
ai-an10:21.13.1_0: These are the ten powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.”
ai-an10:22.1.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an10:22.2.1_0: “Ānanda, I claim to be assured regarding the teachings that lead to realizing by insight the various different hypotheses.
ai-an10:22.2.2_0: So I am able to teach the Dhamma in appropriate ways to different people. Practicing accordingly, when something exists they’ll know it doesn’t exist. When it doesn’t exist they’ll know it doesn’t exist. When something is inferior. When it is superior they’ll know it’s superior. When it is superior they’ll know it’s not supreme. When it is supreme they’ll know it’s supreme.
ai-an10:22.2.3_0: And they will know or see or realize it in whatever way it should be known or seen or realized. This is possible.
ai-an10:22.2.4_0: But this is the unsurpassable knowledge, that is: truly knowing each and every case.
ai-an10:22.2.5_0: And I say that there is no other knowledge that is better or finer than knowledge.

ai-an10:23.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are things that should be given up by the body, not by speech.
ai-an10:23.1.2_0: There are things that should be given up by speech, not by the body.
ai-an10:23.1.3_0: There are things that should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.
ai-an10:23.2.1_0: And what are the things that should be given up by the body, not by speech?
ai-an10:23.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has committed a certain unskillful offense by way of body.
ai-an10:23.2.3_0: After examination, sensible spiritual companions say this to them:
ai-an10:23.2.4_0: ‘Venerable, you’ve committed a certain unskillful offense by way of body.
ai-an10:23.2.5_0: Please give up that bad bodily conduct and develop good bodily conduct.’
ai-an10:23.2.6_0: When spoken to by their sensible spiritual companions they give up that bad bodily conduct and develop good bodily conduct.
ai-an10:23.2.7_0: These are the things that should be given up by the body, not by speech.
ai-an10:23.3.1_0: And what are the things that should be given up by speech, not by the body?
ai-an10:23.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has committed a certain unskillful offense by way of speech.
ai-an10:23.3.3_0: After examination, sensible spiritual companions say this to them:
ai-an10:23.3.4_0: ‘Venerable, you’ve committed a certain unskillful offense by way of speech.
ai-an10:23.3.5_0: Please give up that bad verbal conduct and develop good verbal conduct.’
ai-an10:23.3.6_0: When spoken to by their sensible spiritual companions they give up that bad verbal conduct and develop good verbal conduct.
ai-an10:23.3.7_0: These are the things that should be given up by speech, not by the body.
ai-an10:23.4.1_0: And what are the things that should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom?
ai-an10:23.4.2_0: greed should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.
ai-an10:23.4.9_0: Corrupt wishes should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.
ai-an10:23.5.1_0: Nasty jealousy should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.
ai-an10:23.5.3_0: It’s when a householder or their child is prospering in money, grain, silver, or gold.
ai-an10:23.5.4_0: And a bondservant or dependent thinks:
ai-an10:23.5.5_0: ‘Oh, may that householder or their child not prosper in money, grain, silver, or gold!’
ai-an10:23.5.6_0: Or an ascetic or brahmin receives robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an10:23.5.8_0: ‘Oh, may that ascetic or brahmin not receive robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.’
ai-an10:23.6.1_0: Corrupt wishes should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.
ai-an10:23.6.3_0: It’s when a faithless person wishes to be known as faithful.
ai-an10:23.6.4_0: An unethical person wishes to be known as ethical.
ai-an10:23.6.5_0: An uneducated person wishes to be known as learned.

ai-an10:23.6.7_0: A lazy person wishes to be known as energetic.
ai-an10:23.6.8_0: An unmindful person wishes to be known as mindful.
ai-an10:23.6.9_0: A person without immersion wishes to be known as having immersion.
ai-an10:23.6.10_0: A witless person wishes to be known as wise.
ai-an10:23.6.11_0: A person who has not ended the defilements wishes to be known as having ended the defilements.
ai-an10:23.6.13_0: Corrupt wishes should be given up neither by the body, nor by speech, but by seeing again and again with wisdom.

ai-an10:26.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kurararaghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-an10:26.1.2_0: Then the laywoman Kāḷī of Kuraghara went to Venerable Mahākaccāna,
ai-an10:26.1.2_1: after approaching and worshipping the venerable Mahākaccāna, he sat down on one side.
ai-an10:26.1.2_2: While sitting on one side the laywomen said this to Mahākaccāna:
ai-an10:26.1.3_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Maidens’ Questions’:
ai-an10:26.2.1_0: ‘I’ve reached the goal, peace of heart.
ai-an10:26.2.2_0: Having conquered the army of the likable and pleasant,

ai-an10:29.12.2_0: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color, red hue, and red tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
ai-an10:29.12.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
ai-an10:29.12.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.12.5_0: This is the seventh means of (mind) mastery.
ai-an10:29.13.1_0: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.2_0: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color, white hue, and white tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.3_0: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.13.4_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.13.5_0: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
ai-an10:29.13.6_0: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.
ai-an10:29.14.1_0: The best of these dimensions of mastery is when someone, not perceiving form internally, sees visions externally, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
ai-an10:29.14.2_0: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
ai-an10:29.14.3_0: Some sentient beings perceive like this.
ai-an10:29.14.4_0: But even the sentient beings who perceive like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.14.5_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.
ai-an10:29.14.6_0: Being disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the tip of the blessing.
ai-an10:29.15.1_0: There are, monastics, these four ways of practice.
ai-an10:29.15.5_0: pleasant practice with slow insight, and
ai-an10:29.15.7_0: These, monastics, are the four ways of practice.
ai-an10:29.16.1_0: The best of these four ways of practice is the pleasant practice with swift insight.
ai-an10:29.16.2_0: Some sentient beings practice like this.
ai-an10:29.16.3_0: But even the sentient beings who practice like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.16.4_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.
ai-an10:29.16.5_0: Being disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the tip of the blessing.
ai-an10:29.17.1_0: There are, monastics, these four perceptions.
ai-an10:29.17.6_0: One person, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, perceives the dimension of nothingness.
ai-an10:29.18.1_0: This is the best of these four perceptions, that is to say: ‘There is nothing at all’,
ai-an10:29.18.2_0: Some sentient beings perceive like this.
ai-an10:29.18.3_0: But even the sentient beings who perceive like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.18.4_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.
ai-an10:29.18.5_0: Being disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the tip of the blessing.
ai-an10:29.19.1_0: This is the best of the convictions of outsiders, that is: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
ai-an10:29.19.2_0: When someone has such a view, you can expect
ai-an10:29.19.3_0: that they will be repulsed by continued existence,
ai-an10:29.19.4_0: and they will not be repulsed by the cessation of continued existence.
ai-an10:29.19.5_0: Some sentient beings have such a view.
ai-an10:29.19.6_0: But even the sentient beings who have views like this decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.19.7_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.
ai-an10:29.19.8_0: Being disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the tip of the blessing.
ai-an10:29.20.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate ultimate purity.
ai-an10:29.20.2_0: This is the best of the advocates of ultimate purity, that is, when someone, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an10:29.20.3_0: and they teach them the Dhamma.
ai-an10:29.20.4_0: Such is the sentient beings who have such doctrines.
ai-an10:29.20.5_0: But even the sentient beings who have such a doctrine decay and perish.
ai-an10:29.20.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.
ai-an10:29.20.7_0: Being disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding the tip of the blessing.
ai-an10:29.21.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate extinguishment in this very life.
ai-an10:29.21.2_0: This is the best of those who advocate extinguishment in this very life, that is, liberation by not grasping after truly understanding the origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape of the six fields of contact.
ai-an10:29.21.3_0: Though I speak and explain like this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the false, hollow, lying, untruthful claim:
ai-an10:29.21.4_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama doesn’t advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, sights, or feelings.’
ai-an10:29.21.5_0: But I do advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, sights, and feelings. And I advocate complete extinguishment by not grasping in this very life, wishless, extinguished, and cooled.”
ai-an10:30.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:30.1.2_0: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala returned from combat after winning a battle and succeeding in his objective.
ai-an10:30.1.3_0: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went to the monastery.
ai-an10:30.1.4_0: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.
ai-an10:30.1.5_0: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.
ai-an10:30.1.6_0: King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to them and said,
ai-an10:30.1.7_0: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?
ai-an10:30.1.8_0: For we want to see him.”
ai-an10:30.1.9_0: “Great king, that’s his dwelling, with the door closed.
ai-an10:30.1.9_1: where he went to him, put him down, lifted up his robe on the edge of the shell.
ai-an10:30.2.1_0: Then the king approached the Buddha’s dwelling and knocked, and the Buddha opened the door.
ai-an10:30.2.2_0: Then King Pasenadi entered the Buddha’s dwelling. He bowed with his head to the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
ai-an10:30.2.3_0: “Sirs, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!
ai-an10:30.2.4_0: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”
ai-an10:30.3.1_0: “But great king, for what reason do you demonstrate such utmost devotion for this body, conveying your manifest love?”
ai-an10:30.3.2_0: “Sir, it’s because of my gratitude and thanks for the Buddha that I demonstrate such utmost devotion, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.4.1_0: For the Buddha practices for the welfare and happiness of the people, on account of the noble ones, and once established in the true teaching.
ai-an10:30.4.2_0: This is a reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.5.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is mature, noble, and skillful.
ai-an10:30.5.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.6.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha lives in the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
ai-an10:30.6.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.7.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an10:30.7.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.8.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
ai-an10:30.8.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.9.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when he wants, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an10:30.9.2_0: This is another reason that someone gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-an10:30.9.2_1: That’s the reason why I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love. That’s another reason for my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.10.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-an10:30.10.2_0: This is another reason that I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.11.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha recollects many kinds of past lives. That is:
ai-an10:30.11.1_1: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths.
ai-an10:30.11.1_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food.
ai-an10:30.11.1_3: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-an10:30.11.2_0: This is a power of the Buddha.
ai-an10:30.11.2_1: That’s how I see this reason.
ai-an10:30.12.1_0: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-an10:30.12.1_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-an10:30.12.1_2: They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an10:30.12.1_3: and he knows beings arise according to their (good and bad) actions...
ai-an10:30.12.2_1: Since this is so, I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.13.1_0: Furthermore, the Buddha has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-an10:30.13.2_0: This is a power that the Buddha has ended the defilements.
ai-an10:30.13.2_1: Seeing this, I demonstrate such utmost devotion for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.
ai-an10:30.14.1_0: Well, now, sir, I must go.
ai-an10:30.14.2_0: I have many duties, and much to do.”
ai-an10:30.14.3_0: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
ai-an10:30.14.4_0: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-an10:30.14.6_0: The third sub-chapter on logs is finished.
ai-an10:30.15.1_0: And because they do have entered their bodies with their body
ai-an10:31.1.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli approached the Buddha,
ai-an10:31.1.2_0: “Sir, for how many reasons did the Realized One lay down training rules for his disciples and recite the monastic code?”
ai-an10:31.2.1_0: “Upāli, the Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for ten reasons.
ai-an10:31.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:31.2.3_0: for the well-being of the Saṅgha and for the comfort of the Saṅgha. For keeping difficult persons in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. For restraining defilements that affect the present life and protecting against defilements that affect lives to come. For inspiring confidence in those without it, and increasing confidence in those who have it. For the continuation of the true teaching and the support of the training.
ai-an10:31.2.4_0: The Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for these ten reasons.”
ai-an10:32.1.1_0: “Sir, how many kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code are there?”
ai-an10:32.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.
ai-an10:32.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:32.1.4_0: someone seated in that gathering has committed an offense entailing expulsion; there is an unfinished discussion on anyone who is not fully ordained; there is an unfinished discussion on the training; a _paṇḍaka_; a group of _paṇḍaka_; one who has committed an offense entailing expulsion; one who hasn’t renounced it; there is an unfinished discussion on anyone else topics that discussion.
ai-an10:32.1.5_0: These are the ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.”
ai-an10:33.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be agreed on as a judge?”
ai-an10:33.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.
ai-an10:33.1.4_1: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:33.1.5_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an10:33.1.6_0: He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
ai-an10:33.1.7_0: One who is firmly committed to the Monastic Law.
ai-an10:33.1.8_0: When there are opposing parties, they’re able to persuade, advocate, and convince them, make them see the other side and trust each other.
ai-an10:33.1.9_0: They’re skilled in raising and settling disciplinary issues.
ai-an10:33.1.10_0: They know what a disciplinary issue is.
ai-an10:33.1.11_0: One who understands the arising of legal issues.
ai-an10:33.1.12_0: They know how a disciplinary issue ceases.
ai-an10:33.1.13_0: They know the practical way leading to the cessation of a disciplinary issue.
ai-an10:33.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.”
ai-an10:34.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give ordination?”
ai-an10:34.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give ordination.
ai-an10:34.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:34.1.5_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an10:34.1.6_0: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
ai-an10:34.1.7_0: He’s capable of three things in regard to a sick person.
ai-an10:34.1.8_0: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
ai-an10:34.1.9_0: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.
ai-an10:34.1.10_0: They’re able to make a view that has arisen in the Teaching.
ai-an10:34.1.11_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,
ai-an10:34.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to give ordination.”
ai-an10:35.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give dependence?”
ai-an10:35.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give dependence.
ai-an10:35.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical ...
ai-an10:35.1.6_0: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
ai-an10:35.1.7_0: He’s capable of three things in regard to a sick person.
ai-an10:35.1.8_0: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
ai-an10:35.1.9_0: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.
ai-an10:35.1.10_0: They’re able to make a view that has arisen in the Teaching.
ai-an10:35.1.11_0: They’re able to settle the higher ethics. ...
ai-an10:35.1.13_0: to encourage others in the higher wisdom.
ai-an10:35.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to give dependence.”
ai-an10:36.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be attended on by a novice?”
ai-an10:36.1.2_0: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.
ai-an10:36.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical ...
ai-an10:36.1.6_0: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
ai-an10:36.1.7_0: He’s capable of three things in regard to a sick person.
ai-an10:36.1.8_0: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
ai-an10:36.1.9_0: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.
ai-an10:36.1.10_0: They’re able to make a view that has arisen in the Teaching.
ai-an10:36.1.11_0: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,
ai-an10:36.1.14_0: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.”
ai-an10:36.1.15_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an10:37.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:37.1.2_0: How is schism in the Saṅgha defined?”
ai-an10:37.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:37.1.4_0: On these ten grounds they split off and go their own way. They perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.
ai-an10:37.1.5_0: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”
ai-an10:38.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘harmony in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:38.1.2_0: How is harmony in the Saṅgha defined?”
ai-an10:38.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:38.1.4_0: On these ten grounds they don’t split off and go their own way. They don’t perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.
ai-an10:38.1.5_0: then there is unity in the Sangha.”
ai-an10:39.1.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-an10:39.1.1_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-an10:39.1.2_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:39.1.3_0: How is schism in the Saṅgha defined?”
ai-an10:39.1.4_0: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching ...
ai-an10:39.1.5_0: and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:39.1.6_0: On these ten grounds they split off and go their own way. They perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.
ai-an10:39.1.7_0: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”
ai-an10:39.2.1_0: “But, Sir, what is the consequence of causing a schism in a united Sangha?”
ai-an10:39.2.2_0: “They bring upon themselves evil that lasts for an eon.”
ai-an10:39.2.3_0: “But sir, what is the evil that lasts for an eon?”
ai-an10:39.2.4_0: “They burn in hell for an eon, Ānanda.
ai-an10:39.3.2_0: in a place of loss, in hell.
ai-an10:39.3.5_0: After causing schism in a harmonious Saṅgha,
ai-an10:39.3.6_0: they burn in hell for an eon.”
ai-an10:40.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘harmony in the Saṅgha’.
ai-an10:40.1.2_0: How is harmony in the Saṅgha defined?”
ai-an10:40.1.3_0: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:40.1.4_0: On these ten grounds they don’t split off and go their own way. They don’t perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.
ai-an10:40.1.5_0: then there is unity in the Sangha.”
ai-an10:40.2.1_0: “But sir, what does someone who has created harmony in a schismatic Saṅgha bring upon themselves?”
ai-an10:40.3.1_0: A Saṅgha in harmony is happy,
ai-an10:40.3.2_0: as is support for those in harmony.
ai-an10:40.3.3_0: Taking a stand on the teaching,
ai-an10:40.3.6_0: He rejoices in heaven for an eon.’”
ai-an10:40.3.8_0: The fourth sub-chapter on Upāli is finished.
ai-an10:41.1.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli approached the Buddha,
ai-an10:41.1.2_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason, why arguments, quarrels, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily?”
ai-an10:41.1.3_0: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:41.1.4_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why arguments, quarrels, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily.”
ai-an10:42.1.1_0: “Sir, how many roots of arguments are there?”
ai-an10:42.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten roots of arguments.
ai-an10:42.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as the training, and what is the training as not the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.
ai-an10:42.1.5_0: These are the ten roots of arguments.”
ai-an10:43.1.1_0: “Sir, how many roots of arguments are there?”
ai-an10:43.1.2_0: “Upāli, there are ten roots of arguments.
ai-an10:43.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not an offense as an offense, and what is an offense as not an offense. They explain a light offense as a serious offense, and a serious offense as a light offense. They explain an offense committed with corrupt intention as an offense committed with corrupt intention, and an offense not committed with corrupt intention as an offense committed with corrupt intention. They explain an offense requiring rehabilitation, and an offense not requiring rehabilitation. They explain an offense with redress as an offense without redress, and an offense without redres as an offense with redress, and an offense without redress as an offense with redress.
ai-an10:43.1.5_0: These are the ten roots of arguments.”
ai-an10:44.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings.
ai-an10:44.2.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check five things in themselves and establish five things in themselves.
ai-an10:44.2.2_0: What five things should they check in themselves?
ai-an10:44.2.3_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.2.4_0: ‘Is my bodily behavior pure? Do I have pure bodily behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?
ai-an10:44.2.5_0: Is this thing found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.2.6_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.2.7_0: ‘Please train your own bodily conduct first.’
ai-an10:44.3.1_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.3.2_0: ‘Is my verbal behavior pure? Do I have pure verbal behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?
ai-an10:44.3.3_0: Is this thing found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.3.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.3.5_0: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own verbal behavior first.’
ai-an10:44.4.1_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.4.2_0: ‘Is my heart established in love for my spiritual companions, without resentment?
ai-an10:44.4.3_0: Is this thing found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.4.4_0: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
ai-an10:44.4.5_0: ‘Come on, venerable, establish your heart in love for your spiritual companions first.’
ai-an10:44.5.1_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.5.2_0: ‘Am I very learned, remembering and keeping what I’ve learned? These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. Am I very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically?
ai-an10:44.5.3_0: Is this thing found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.5.4_0: If it’s not, there will be those who say,
ai-an10:44.6.1_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
ai-an10:44.6.2_0: ‘Have both monastic codes been passed down to me in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, and well judged in both the rules and accompanying material?
ai-an10:44.6.3_0: Is this thing found in me or not?’
ai-an10:44.6.4_0: If they’re not included in both the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in detail, then they won’t answer it properly.
ai-an10:44.6.6_0: ‘Come on, venerable, train in the code of conduct first.’
ai-an10:44.6.7_0: These are the five things they should check in themselves.
ai-an10:44.7.1_0: What five things should they establish in themselves?
ai-an10:44.7.2_0: ‘I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.
ai-an10:44.7.3_0: I’ll speak the truth, not falsehood;
ai-an10:44.7.5_0: I’ll speak what’s beneficial, not what’s unbeneficial;
ai-an10:44.7.6_0: I’ll speak with a mind of good will, not with internal ill will.’”
ai-an10:44.7.7_0: These are the five things they should establish in themselves.
ai-an10:44.7.8_0: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check these five things in themselves and establish these five things in themselves.”
ai-an10:45.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are ten drawbacks to entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:45.1.3_0: Firstly, a king is sitting with his chief queen
ai-an10:45.1.5_0: When the queen sees the monk she smiles, or when the monk sees the queen he smiles.
ai-an10:45.1.7_0: ‘Surely they’ve done it, or they’re going to.’
ai-an10:45.1.8_0: This is the first drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.2.1_0: Furthermore, a king has many duties, and much to do. He has sex with one of the women but doesn’t remember.
ai-an10:45.2.6_0: This is the second drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.3.1_0: Again, a gem disappears from the royal compound.
ai-an10:45.3.5_0: This is the third drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.4.1_0: Again, secret discussions in the royal compound are spread outside.
ai-an10:45.4.5_0: This is the fourth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.5.1_0: Again, in the royal compound a father assails his son, or a son assails his father.
ai-an10:45.5.5_0: This is the fifth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.6.1_0: Furthermore, the king promotes someone to a higher position.
ai-an10:45.6.2_0: Those who are upset by this think:
ai-an10:45.6.3_0: ‘The king is close to the monk.
ai-an10:45.6.5_0: This is the sixth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.7.2_0: Those who are upset by this think:
ai-an10:45.7.3_0: ‘The king is close to the monk.
ai-an10:45.7.5_0: This is the seventh drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.8.1_0: Furthermore, the king dispatches the army at the wrong time.
ai-an10:45.8.2_0: Those who are upset by this think:
ai-an10:45.8.3_0: ‘The king is close to the monk.
ai-an10:45.8.5_0: This is the eighth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.9.1_0: Again, after sending out the army at an appropriate time, the king orders it to turn back while still en route.
ai-an10:45.9.2_0: Those who are upset by this think:
ai-an10:45.9.3_0: ‘The king is close to the monk.
ai-an10:45.9.5_0: This is the ninth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.10.1_0: Furthermore, in the royal harem there is a trampling of elephants, horses, and chariots, as well as arousing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches that do not befit a monk.
ai-an10:45.10.2_0: This is the tenth drawback of entering a royal harem.
ai-an10:45.10.3_0: Monks, these are the ten dangers in entering a royal compound.”
ai-an10:46.1.1_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling amongst the Sakyas, near to Kapilavatthu, in Nigrodha’s Monastery.
ai-an10:46.1.2_0: Then on the observance day several lay followers went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an10:46.1.2_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-an10:46.1.3_0: “Sakyans, do you observe the sabbath with its eight factors?”
ai-an10:46.1.4_0: “Sir, sometimes we do, sometimes we don’t.”
ai-an10:46.1.5_0: “That’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.
ai-an10:46.2.2_0: Take a man who earns half a dollar for an honest day’s work.
ai-an10:46.2.3_0: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
ai-an10:46.3.2_0: Take a man who earns a dollar for an honest day’s work.
ai-an10:46.3.3_0: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
ai-an10:46.4.2_0: Take a man who, for an honest day’s work, earns two dollars ...
ai-an10:46.4.16_0: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
ai-an10:46.5.2_0: Suppose that man earned a hundred or a thousand dollars every day and saved it all up. If he lived for a hundred years, would he not accumulate a large mass of wealth?”
ai-an10:46.6.2_0: Would that man, on account of that wealth, experience perfect happiness for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?”
ai-an10:46.6.5_0: “Because sensual pleasures, sir, are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.”
ai-an10:46.7.1_0: “But take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for ten years, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years.
ai-an10:46.7.2_0: And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
ai-an10:46.8.1_0: take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for nine years ...
ai-an10:46.8.9_0: Let alone two years, take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for one day, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years. And they could become a once-returner or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
ai-an10:46.10.1_0: take one of my disciples who lives here ...
ai-an10:46.11.2_0: Let alone ten days and nights,
ai-an10:46.12.9_0: Let alone two days, take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for one day, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years. And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
ai-an10:46.12.10_0: It’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.”
ai-an10:46.12.11_0: “Well, sir, from this day forth we will observe the sabbath with its eight factors.”
ai-an10:46.12.12_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an10:47.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an10:47.1.2_0: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha.
ai-an10:47.1.2_2: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-an10:47.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds?”
ai-an10:47.1.4_0: “Greed is a cause, Mahāli, greed is a reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.
ai-an10:47.1.5_0: Hate is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.6_0: Delusion is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.7_0: Improper attention is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.8_0: A wrongly directed mind is a cause of bad deeds ...
ai-an10:47.1.9_0: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.”
ai-an10:47.2.1_0: “But sir, what is the cause, what is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds?”
ai-an10:47.2.2_0: “Contentment is a cause, Mahāli, contentment is a reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.
ai-an10:47.2.3_0: Love is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.4_0: Understanding is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.5_0: Proper attention is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.6_0: A rightly directed mind is a cause of good deeds ...
ai-an10:47.2.7_0: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.
ai-an10:47.2.8_0: If these ten things were not found in the world, we wouldn’t see either unprincipled and immoral conduct, or principled and moral conduct.
ai-an10:47.2.9_0: But since these ten things are found in the world, they are unprincipled and immoral conduct, or principled and moral conduct.”
ai-an10:48.1.1_0: “Mendicants, one who has gone forth should often review these ten things.
ai-an10:48.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:48.3.1_0: ‘My livelihood is tied up with others.’
ai-an10:48.5.1_0: ‘I hope there’s no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct?’
ai-an10:48.6.1_0: ‘I hope that, after examination, sensible spiritual companions don’t reproach any aspect of my ethics?’
ai-an10:48.7.1_0: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’
ai-an10:48.8.1_0: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
ai-an10:48.9.1_0: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’
ai-an10:48.10.1_0: ‘As the days and nights flit by, what sort of person am I becoming?’
ai-an10:48.11.1_0: ‘I hope that in an empty dwelling, I hope you’re in an empty dwelling,
ai-an10:48.12.1_0: ‘Do I have any superhuman distinctions in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, so that when my spiritual companions question me on my deathbed I will not be embarrassed?’
ai-an10:48.13.1_0: One who has gone forth should often review these ten things.”
ai-an10:49.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:49.1.3_0: Cold, heat, hunger, thirst, feces, urine, restraint of body, speech, and livelihood, and the will to live that leads to future lives.
ai-an10:49.1.4_0: These ten things exist because of the body.”
ai-an10:50.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:50.1.2_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall. They were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-an10:50.2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall.
ai-an10:50.2.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-an10:50.2.3_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
ai-an10:50.3.1_0: “Sir, after the meal, on return from alms-round, we sat together in the assembly hall, arguing, quarreling, and disputing, wounding each other with barbed words.”
ai-an10:50.3.2_0: “Mendicants, this is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-an10:50.4.1_0: There are ten warm-hearted qualities that make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.4.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
ai-an10:50.4.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-an10:50.4.5_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.5.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an10:50.5.2_0: When a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.
ai-an10:50.5.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.6.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates. ...
ai-an10:50.6.2_0: When a mendicant has good friends,
ai-an10:50.6.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.7.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
ai-an10:50.7.2_0: When a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish.
ai-an10:50.7.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.8.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work. ...
ai-an10:50.8.2_0: When a mendicant is skilled and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties, this is an outcome of duties.
ai-an10:50.8.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.9.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.
ai-an10:50.9.2_0: When a mendicant loves the teachings, this is a delight to converse with,
ai-an10:50.9.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.10.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities. ...
ai-an10:50.10.2_0: When a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities,
ai-an10:50.10.3_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.11.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an10:50.11.2_0: When a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick,
ai-an10:50.11.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.12.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
ai-an10:50.12.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.13.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an10:50.13.2_0: When a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an10:50.13.3_0: this warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, helping the Saṅgha to live in harmony and unity, without quarreling.
ai-an10:50.14.1_0: These ten warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.”
ai-an10:50.14.3_0: The fifth sub-chapter on nakedness is finished.

ai-an10:51.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an10:51.2.1_0: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
ai-an10:51.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in pairs?
ai-an10:51.3.2_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
ai-an10:51.3.3_0: If they see any dirt, they’re happy in that place.
ai-an10:51.3.5_0: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.
ai-an10:51.3.6_0: ‘Am I often covetous or not? Am I often malicious or not? Am I often overcome with dullness and drowsiness or not? Am I often restless or not? Am I often doubtful or not? Am I often irritable or not? Am I often corrupted in mind or not? Am I often disturbed in body or not? Am I often energetic or not? Am I often immersed in samādhi or not?’
ai-an10:51.4.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an10:51.4.2_0: ‘I am often covetous, malicious, overcome with dullness and drowsiness, restless, doubtful, irritable, defiled in mind, disturbed in body, lazy, and not immersed in samādhi.’ In order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an10:51.4.3_0: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire.
ai-an10:51.4.3_1: If that head were on fire, we’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an10:51.4.4_0: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm ...
ai-an10:51.5.1_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an10:51.5.2_0: ‘I am often content, kind-hearted, free of dullness and drowsiness, calm, confident, loving, pure in mind, undisturbed in body, energetic, and immersed in samādhi.’ Grounded on those skillful qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”

ai-an10:52.6.2_1: “Reverend, I am often immersed in samādhi.” Then they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”
ai-an10:53.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I don’t praise stagnation in skillful qualities, let alone decline.
ai-an10:53.1.2_0: I praise growth in skillful qualities, not stagnation or decline.
ai-an10:53.2.1_0: And how is there stagnation in skillful qualities, not stagnation or growth?
ai-an10:53.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has a certain degree of faith, ethics, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence. Those qualities neither stagnate nor grow in them.
ai-an10:53.2.3_0: I call this decline in skillful qualities, not stagnation or growth.

ai-an10:53.5.1_0: If a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
ai-an10:53.6.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in pairs?
ai-an10:53.6.2_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
ai-an10:53.6.3_0: If they see any dirt, they’re happy in that place.
ai-an10:53.6.5_0: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.

Am I often irritable or not? Am I often corrupted in mind or not? Am I often disturbed in body or not? Am I often energetic or not? Am I often immersed in samādhi or not?’
ai-an10:53.7.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-an10:53.7.2_0: ‘I am often covetous, malicious, overcome with dullness and drowsiness, restless, doubtful, irritable, defiled in mind, disturbed in body, lazy, and not immersed in samādhi.’ In order to give up those bad, unskillful qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
ai-an10:53.7.3_0: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire.

ai-an10:53.8.2_0: ‘I am often content, kind-hearted, free of dullness and drowsiness, calm, confident, loving, pure in mind, undisturbed in body, energetic, and immersed in samādhi.’ Grounded on those skillful qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”
